data.text: Contents
Process for Receiving the Verbal Prescribing Order ........................................................... 9
Raising Concerns with a Verbal Prescribing Order ........................................................... 10
Introduction

Obtaining, supplying and/or administering medication for a patient requires a legally valid written prescription, prescription order or other valid written document such as a patient group direction (PGD) or patient specific direction (PSD).

In some circumstances, however, this is not possible, in the course of safely treating patients at the Trust. In exceptional circumstances there is a need for a prescriber to give a verbal prescription order to treat a patient.
Verbal prescribing order instructions may be used to authorise the administration or discontinuation (permanent or temporary) of medication.

Safety is the overriding principle in accepting a verbal order because they have a high potential for, and have resulted in, harmful errors. Orders can be misheard, misinterpreted and/or mis-transcribed.
There are two scenarios where verbal orders may occur;
remotely by telephone or electronic memorandum (i.e. a scanned paper prescription/attachment in an email);
OR
in the presence of a medical practitioner (i.e. whilst undertaking an emergency procedure).
Verbal orders must be aligned to the principles outlined in the Trust Prescribing Policy and Trust Administration of Medicines Policy.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Outline a clear framework for when and where verbal orders may be used;
Detail a clear process to follow when a verbal prescribing order is made.
This applies to all prescribers and registered nursing/midwifery/ODP/pharmacy staff in all wards and departments with exceptions as outlined within this document.

This document does not comprehensively cover prescribing amendments undertaken within the professional course of practice by registered pharmacists and registered pharmacy technicians (except as itemised in section 5.5). Please refer to site pharmacy departmental procedures.
Definitions

table_items.text: In the context of this policy; clinical situations where the patient is experiencing a life threatening acute episode. Common life threatening acute episodes include cardiac arrest, respiratory arrest, hypoglycaemia, hyperglycaemia, hypovolaemic shock, anaphylactic shock and cardiogenic shock.

In the context of this policy; where it is physically impossible to provide a written prescription and Wellsky ePMA does not exist to enable remote prescribing (i.e. prescriber has been detained and cannot attend the patient for some time or is unable to complete a prescription due to treating the patient); AND / OR it is an emergency situation where immediate treatment is required for the patient, and delay in writing a prescription would adversely affect patient outcome (i.e. would likely lead to harm).

A prescribing request said out aloud to another registered practitioner to administer a medicine, or prepare a dose to administer, in the absence of a valid legally written prescription or written prescription order. Also known as a verbal instruction. In the context of this policy this also includes an electronic memorandum (i.e. email), containing instructions or a scanned in document.
The electronic prescribing and administration system used within the Trust in main clinical ward areas, replacing paper charts in a phased approach on all sites.
The electronic prescribing and administration system used within the Critical Care (intensive care) clinical areas on the Broomfield site (at time of publishing).

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
MSE Patient Safety & Quality Group
Receiving exception reports and taking action in response to issues raised from Medicines Assurance Group and/or department of pharmacy.
MSE Medicines Assurance Group
Ensuring the effective implementation, use and timely review of this policy;
Ensuring that monitoring arrangements are appropriately performed by the Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Groups (MOSG);
Where necessary, escalating concerns to the Chief Nursing Officer / Site Directors of Nursing or Chief Medical Officer / Site Medical Directors as appropriate;
Exception reporting to the MSE Patient Safety & Quality Group on developments, concerns and progress concerning verbal prescribing orders.
Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG)
Monitoring this policy through incident reports;
Escalating issues to site divisional governance groups and MAG as appropriate.
Chief Executive

As the Trust's accountable officer has overall responsibility for ensuring the Trust has robust, complete and up to date documents in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
Chief Medical Officer, delegating to Site Medical Directors and Divisional Medical/Clinical Directors
Ensuring that there is policy compliance and liaising with their deputies to assure themselves that the policy is operating effectively by medical staff prescribers;
Ensuring any escalated issues involving verbal prescribing orders involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Chief Nursing Officer, delegating to Site Directors (and deputy directors) of Nursing and Divisional Associate Directors of nursing
Ensuring that there is policy compliance and liaising with their deputies to assure themselves that the policy is operating effectively by all professions they oversee;
Ensuring any escalated verbal prescribing order issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately;
Chief Pharmacist
Setting the overall framework and policy standards for verbal prescribing orders across the organisation, in line with regulatory and best practice guidance;
Ensuring a monitoring process exists and functions for policy standards.
Prescriber of the verbal order
Throughout the whole process the prescriber takes full responsibility for the verbal order.
Making an order exactly as documented in this policy, including the unambiguous confirmation to the person receiving the order that it has been received correctly;
Being fully aware of all of the medicines that the patient is currently prescribed or is taking, within the scope of available information to them (i.e. the written prescriptions);
Adhering to this policy and working within their professional regulatory framework;

Where they administer, documenting their administration of the medicine in the healthcare record (i.e. drug chart or anaesthetic record sheet) as soon as possible after the administration has occurred;
Signing the controlled drug register, as appropriate, in a timely manner afterwards;
Providing a valid written prescription at the earliest opportunity, where appropriate.
Registered authorised person receiving and administering the verbal order
Receiving the order exactly as documented in this policy, including the unambiguous repeating back to the prescriber in full, and personal assurance that request is interpreted exactly as requested;
Ensuring the correct drug/s are administered (or supplied if prescriber is administering). If there is any doubt, this must be re-checked with the prescriber immediately;

Being familiar with the drug, usual dosing and administration. If there is any doubt about the drug or dose, this must be clarified with the BNF or other sources (i.e. Medusa injectable guide for injections), to the registrant's satisfaction before the verbal order is finalised and accepted by them to administer;
Ensure written records on drug charts, patient notes and controlled drugs registers are completed in a timely manner in line with this policy.
Circumstances for Verbal Prescribing Orders
A verbal order must never be taken routinely. It is always preferable for a prescriber to attend the patient personally to write or cancel a prescription.

Where the Trust operates Wellsky ePMA (ePrescribing) there is the facility to write electronic prescriptions remotely from any computer with Wellsky ePMA access (including offsite). As such Wellsky ePMA must always be used to provide a written prescription, not a verbal order, except in an emergency situation (see below).

Where Wellsky ePMA for that specific patient does not exist; or the drug cannot be prescribed in Wellsky ePMA (i.e. some variable rate infusions), the use of information technology i.e. email is the preferred method to verbal orders. On receipt, these emails (or printed attached documents) must be treated as if they were verbal orders in line with this policy.
A telephoned verbal instruction must only ever be used as a last resort, in an emergency situation.
A verbal order (or email as per section 5.3) can only be accepted in exceptional circumstances, namely:

5.5.1 Where it is physically impossible to provide a written prescription and Wellsky ePMA does not exist to enable remote prescribing (i.e. prescriber has been detained and cannot attend the patient for some time);
AND / OR
5.5.2 It is an emergency situation where immediate treatment is required for the patient, and delay in writing a prescription would adversely affect patient outcome (i.e. would likely lead to harm).
Only a registered prescriber may give a verbal order in specific circumstances only as detailed in this policy.

Verbal orders for administration must only ever be taken (accepted) by a registered nurse, registered midwife, registered pharmacist or registered pharmacy technician or registered ODP, and must be recorded in line with this policy.
In Critical Care (intensive care) areas the person receiving the verbal order and acting on it must be a senior registered nurse (band 6 or above), or registered pharmacist.
Verbal prescribing orders are not acceptable for discharge medication (TTAs).
Verbal prescribing orders are not acceptable for any schedule 2 or 3 controlled drug, except as outlined in section 11 of this policy.
Verbal prescribing orders are not acceptable for sedatives or antipsychotics, with the exception of intensive care (critical care) clinical areas.
Required Contents of a Verbal Prescribing Order
A verbal order is one order consisting of up to three individual drugs for a single patient.

A verbal order for initiating the administration of a drug is valid for one dose only; unless specifically specified otherwise (i.e. specific dose aliquots of injection being given in emergency setting, for a limited time period).

The correct patient must be confirmed where not obvious (i.e. you are at bedside in presence of the prescriber in emergency). Always use date of birth and NHS number in the ward environment where similar names/ pronunciations may exist.
There must be a clear rationale given for the verbal order, where not clinically obvious to the registered healthcare professional.
The verbal order for each drug must be given separately; in that all minimum information is given for one drug before the next drug verbal order is given.
The minimum information to be given verbally (or be documented within an email etc.) must be, for each drug:
Drug name – always given as the generic or approved name (international normalised name), unless there is a specific reason to prescribe by brand such as differences in bioavailability;
Dose – always expressed in weight metrics (i.e. mg, micrograms etc. and is never only as a volume i.e. ml); and pronounced in single digits (e.g. 15mg is read out as ‘one five');
Strength /Concentration of the drug, where relevant (e.g. adrenaline, mg/ml etc.);
Formulation (i.e. injection, nebule);
Route ( ‘injection' alone is not acceptable as it is not a route – intravenous is acceptable);
Right time to be given – this will be immediately, with a specific instruction;
Any specific instructions – such as to deliver in aliquots as per the physician's direct order during a procedure, bolus or infusion etc.
Process for Receiving the Verbal Prescribing Order
The registered nurse/midwife/ODP/Pharmacist must focus solely on the verbal order instruction at that time. On receipt of the order they must ask for any missing information from the list above.
The registered nurse/midwife/ODP/pharmacist must verbally repeat back clearly to the prescriber ALL information in the verbal order as above (section 6.6).

The prescriber must confirm by saying the word ‘Yes – correct' to each part of the order to verify it has been interpreted correctly. If Yes is not clearly spoken the registered nurse/midwife/ODP must repeat the verbal order to the prescriber and/or re-clarify the entire order verbally.
If the second registered nurse/midwife/ODP/pharmacist (where present) does not fully understand the rationale for the request, they must challenge the prescriber and not prepare the medicine.
Example clarifications could be:
‘could you clarify the reason, drug/dose and/or route etc.' as appropriate;
‘I am familiar with giving X like this but not what you have said, could you confirm I have heard you correctly please?'

Saying ‘Yes' is the only acceptable confirmation for all aspects of verbal orders. Nodding of the head or similar non-verbal signals (and ‘Aha/Ahem' etc. if over the telephone) is not acceptable, for all staff involved.
Raising Concerns with a Verbal Prescribing Order
Prescribing and administration errors can happen but harm is usually avoided by professional colleagues intervening before the errors can affect patients.

All staff involved in the verbal order process must protect patients from risks of harm posed by colleagues' prescribing, administration and other medicines-related errors. All practitioners should question any decision or action that they consider might be unsafe.
If colleagues raise any concerns about the verbal order responses from the prescriber must be constructive.

All incidents involving any stage of the verbal prescribing orders process must be reported in line with the Trust incident reporting process. Follow MSEPO-20206 - Policy for the Management of and Learning from Medication Errors.
Process in an emergency situation, in presence of the medical
practitioner (prescriber)
In emergency situations written prescriptions may be difficult to obtain and therefore staff may need to prepare and administer medicines on verbal instruction.
The verbal order is received as per section 6 & 7 above.
Once the medication is prepared, and prior to administration, the registered nurse/midwife/ODP must show the medication to the prescriber at the bedside.
The prescriber must undertake a double check of the drug name, dose, strength, formulation, route and specific instructions where relevant, where physically possible to do so.

The registered nurse/midwife/ODP must support the double check by ensuring all aspects of the verbal order (see section 6.6) have been correctly followed. This is to be done by reading out all particulars (as per 6.6) of the prepared medicine to the prescriber.
In all circumstances the prescriber must verbally say ‘Yes' when asked if this is correct to accept the prepared medication. They must say ‘Yes please give' after the checks are made.
Following administration written records must be completed as soon as possible, as per section 13 of this policy.
Process for receiving a verbal order via telephone or email

A registered healthcare professional must hear the verbal order (or read email) directly from the prescriber. In doing so they must obtain full patient name, drug name, dose, strength, form, route, and specific instructions given by the prescriber (in line with section 6.6 above). Where available, a second registrant should witness the verbal/email order.
The order must be repeated back, in full, over the telephone. See section 7.
For emails, all criteria must be verified in the same way, and a new email requested of a new order that includes any missing information.
Make a written record of the verbal order as per section 13.

Once the medication is prepared, but prior to administration, another registered nurse/midwife/ODP must undertake a double check, in full knowledge and witnessing of the verbal telephone order or email.
Verbal Prescribing Orders for Controlled Drugs

In the context of an emergency situation only, (see section 3 definition) there may be clinical necessity for administration of a controlled drug against a verbal order. Typically this is only within critical care (intensive care) areas and within the emergency department (majors/resus).
Principles outlined in MSEPO-20237 Controlled Drugs Policy & Procedures must be followed alongside this policy.
All verbal orders must be obtained as outlined in this policy.
The registered nurse/midwife/ODP supplying the drug from the controlled drug cupboard must make an entry in the controlled drug register at the time of the verbal order. This must include:
Date and time
Patient name (this is paramount, for traceability)
Amount
Enter the words ‘verbal order – from Dr XXXX'.
Stock balance
Process when only two registered staff present

11.5.1 It is acknowledged that in some clinical circumstances there is only one registered nurse/midwife/ODP present alongside the prescriber; and only one person can attend the controlled drug cupboard. In this situation only it is acceptable for only one person to undertake the physical stock balance check.

11.5.2 The second check entry is then completed in the controlled drug register by the prescriber, where administering the medication, at the earliest opportunity afterwards. If the prescriber is not the person administering, they should act as the witness signatory, with the register brought to them to endorse.
Process when three registered staff involved in the process

11.6.1 In some clinical situations there may be three persons involved in the process, because of the availability of staff (i.e. are attending the patient directly). In such situations only, it is acceptable for two registered practitioners to supply the medication from the controlled drug cupboard, and a third to administer. At least one of the ‘supplying' practitioners must witness the administration by the third (usually the prescriber). The administering practitioner must ensure they sign for the administration in the patient health record (i.e. drug chart, anaesthetic record etc.)

11.6.2 Where possible, the ‘supplying' practitioner at the controlled drug cupboard should be the registered staff member who works for that care area, rather than one from a visiting team (e.g. visiting clinical teams in A&E).

11.6.3 It is the responsibility of the registered nurse/midwife/ODP to remind and prompt the prescriber to furnish a legal written prescription (in Wellsky ePMA, Metavision ePMA or on a paper drug chart); or the anaesthetist to ensure anaesthetic chart is completed with drugs given. This must be done immediately after the clinical situation deems it safe to do so.
11.6.4 The prescriber is responsible for furnishing a legal written prescription as soon as they are physically able to.
Verbal instruction to cancel or suspend administration of a medicine
Documentation of all records must be made as per section 13 in addition to below.
The verbal order received must be read back as per this policy, and this must include confirming the duration that the discontinuation is valid for.
Paper Drug charts

12.3.1  If the verbal message is for the temporary suspension of administration (e.g. for a few doses only, with the recommencement of administration) the appropriate administration boxes on the paper drug chart must be crossed through.
If a prescription is to be cancelled completely, the medicine (approved name) box should be crossed through along with the administration section on the paper drug chart.

The entry must be clearly marked ‘VERBAL INSTRUCTION' and the name of the registered nurse or midwife receiving the verbal instruction must be printed in BLOCK CAPITALS and be followed by their signature, the name of the prescriber and the date and time that the verbal instruction was received.
The prescriber must sign the prescription as soon as possible and always within 24 hours.
Wellsky ePMA

12.7.1 The prescriber must be advised to log into the system remotely and undertake the suspension/discontinuation of the prescription themselves. Registered nurses/midwives will not have access to edit the prescription within Wellsky ePMA. Registered pharmacists are authorised to do this on the prescriber's behalf, where they are satisfied as to validity of the verbal order request to cancel/suspend the medicine prescribed.

12.7.2 In exceptional circumstance where this is not possible, follow section 13.2. It must be noted that the ePMA system will still allow a prescription to be ‘signed for' as administered until it is suspended or discontinued by a prescriber on the Wellsky system.
Metavision ePMA

12.8.1 If the verbal message is for the temporary suspension of administration (e.g. for a few doses only, with the recommencement of administration), the prescriber must be advised to log into the system remotely and undertake the suspension of the prescription themselves. Registered Nurses/Midwives will not have access to edit the prescription within Metavision ePMA.
12.8.2 Always document as a ‘verbal order' event as per section 13.3.
Written records of verbal orders

Verbal prescribing orders must be recorded on the drug chart or anaesthetic record and where practical within the patient's medical notes by the registered person accepting the order (e.g. any additional information to be followed up etc.). This must be done if an email sent (see 13.5.1).
Wellsky ePMA – not applicable. A prescription must be made remotely before administration.
Metavision ePMA

13.3.1 Always document as a ‘Verbal Order' event. Within the comments section enter the name of the prescriber, the date and the time the verbal instruction was received, and the name of the registered nurse receiving the verbal order.
13.3.2 Write within the note all minimum information of the verbal order (as above: drug name /dose/ strength/ form/ route/ specific instructions).
13.3.3 An arrangement must be made for the prescriber to provide a written prescription countersigned as soon as possible, and always within 24 hours.
Paper drug charts
13.4.1 Always document on the ‘once-only' section, or other locally approved section (anaesthetic record drug/notes section etc.).

13.4.2 The entry must be clearly marked 'VERBAL ORDER' and the name of the registered nurse, midwife or pharmacist receiving the verbal order must be printed in BLOCK CAPITALS and be followed by their signature and the name of the prescriber, the date and the time the verbal instruction was received.
13.4.3 Detail in the relevant boxes in the prescribing area all minimum information of the verbal order (as above: drug name /dose/ strength/ form/ route/ specific instructions).
13.4.4 The person administering must record the time, date and initials against the medicine in the normal way.
13.4.5 An arrangement must be made for the prescriber to countersign the order on the drug chart (or anaesthetic record) as soon as possible, and always within 24 hours.
Patient medical notes (regardless of type of drug chart)
13.5.1  Always document a record which mirrors that entered on the drug chart. The following details must be written by the registered nurse/midwife/ODP/pharmacist accepting the verbal order:
The words ‘verbal order' printed clearly in BLOCK CAPITALS;
Date and time the verbal order was received;
Full name and practice of the doctor;
A contact number for the doctor;
Reason for the verbal order;
All minimum information of the verbal order (as above: drug name /dose/ strength/ form/ route/ specific instructions);
Name and qualification of the registered nurse/midwife;
Names of the witnesses to the verbal order;
Include a printed copy of the email in the notes if this is provided as the ‘verbal order'.
Training Requirements

No specific training requirements though verbal orders should be covered in registered nursing/midwifery/ODP induction programme for clinical areas which need to use verbal orders in the course of their practice (i.e. Emergency department, critical care(intensive care), theatres) etc.

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Medicines Assurance Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local medication documents. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the clinical divisions of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
